definition: lasting for a very short time
exampleSentence: The ephemeral nature of fashion trends makes it difficult for retailers to plan their inventory.
synonym1Definition: lasting only for a short time; impermanent
synonym1ExampleSentence: The beauty of cherry blossoms is transient, lasting only a few days each spring.
synonym2Definition: passing quickly; lasting only a brief time
synonym2ExampleSentence: She caught a fleeting glimpse of the rare bird before it disappeared into the forest.
synonym3Definition: lasting for a very short time; brief
synonym3ExampleSentence: There was a momentary silence before the audience erupted in applause.

exampleSentence: Smartphones have become ubiquitous in modern society, with people of all ages using them daily.
synonym1Definition: present everywhere at the same time
synonym1ExampleSentence: In modern society, technology has become omnipresent in our daily lives.
synonym2Definition: spreading widely throughout an area or a group of people
synonym2ExampleSentence: The pervasive influence of social media has transformed how we communicate.
synonym3Definition: existing or affecting everywhere or everyone
synonym3ExampleSentence: The desire for happiness seems to be a universal human trait.

definition: the occurrence of fortunate discoveries by accident
exampleSentence: The discovery of penicillin was a case of serendipity when Alexander Fleming noticed mold killing bacteria in his petri dishes.
synonym1Definition: a possibility of something happening; an opportunity
synonym1ExampleSentence: They met by chance at a coffee shop and became lifelong friends.
synonym2Definition: a chance occurrence, especially a fortunate one
synonym2ExampleSentence: By a happy fortuity, she found the perfect job just when she needed it most.
synonym3Definition: success or failure apparently brought by chance rather than through one's own actions
synonym3ExampleSentence: It was pure luck that we arrived just as they were giving away free tickets.

definition: a departure from what is normal, usual, or expected
exampleSentence: The recent drop in temperature is an aberration for this time of year, as it's typically much warmer in July.
synonym1Definition: something that deviates from what is standard, normal, or expected
synonym1ExampleSentence: The unusually cold summer was an anomaly in the region's typically warm climate.
synonym2Definition: the action of departing from an established course or standard
synonym2ExampleSentence: Any deviation from the recipe could affect the final taste of the dish.
synonym3Definition: a thing that is irregular in form, amount, or occurrence
synonym3ExampleSentence: The doctor noticed an irregularity in the patient's heartbeat.

definition: to regard with disgust and hatred
exampleSentence: Many people abhor cruelty to animals and support laws that protect them from mistreatment.
synonym1ExampleSentence: She detests violence in any form and always advocates for peaceful solutions.
synonym2Definition: to feel intense dislike or disgust for
synonym2ExampleSentence: He loathes getting up early on weekends after a long work week.
synonym3Definition: to feel contempt or a deep repugnance for
synonym3ExampleSentence: Many people despise dishonesty and value truthfulness in their relationships.

definition: to accept something reluctantly but without protest
exampleSentence: Though she disagreed with the decision, she acquiesced to her manager's plan to avoid conflict in the workplace.
synonym1Definition: to act in accordance with a wish or command
synonym1ExampleSentence: The student complied with the teacher's request to rewrite the essay.
synonym2Definition: to give permission for something to happen
synonym2ExampleSentence: After much discussion, her parents finally consented to let her attend the concert.
synonym3Definition: to give way to arguments, demands, or pressure
synonym3ExampleSentence: The committee yielded to public pressure and reversed their decision.
